summary: This document is an internal communication from the Chief Psychologist at the Metropolitan Correctional Center regarding Jeffrey Epstein's housing and suicide prevention. It discusses a suggestion from a National Suicide Prevention Coordinator to house Epstein with another sex offender in the SHU and notes the plan to keep him in restrictive housing.

persons.name: Dr. [Redacted]
persons.context: Contacted the Chief Psychologist to suggest housing Jeffrey Epstein with another sex offender in the SHU as a suicide prevention measure.

persons.name: [Redacted], Psy.D.
persons.context: Author of the correspondence, discussing Epstein's housing arrangements and suicide prevention suggestions with executive staff.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the discussion regarding housing arrangements and suicide prevention measures at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

connections.description: Colleagues within the Bureau of Prisons system discussing inmate management and suicide prevention protocols.
National Suicide Prevention Coordinator making recommendations about Epstein's housing for suicide prevention.
Chief Psychologist responsible for Epstein's psychological care and housing arrangements at the correctional center.

events.title: Suicide Prevention Discussion for Epstein
events.description: Internal discussion about housing Jeffrey Epstein with another sex offender in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) as a suicide prevention measure.

locations.name: Metropolitan Correctional Center
locations.address: 150 Park Row, New York, New York 10007
locations.context: Federal detention facility where Jeffrey Epstein was held; location of the correspondence.

keyFacts: A National Suicide Prevention Coordinator suggested housing Jeffrey Epstein with another sex offender in the SHU as a suicide prevention measure.
The Chief Psychologist agreed with the existing plan to keep Epstein in restrictive housing ('keep him down here for a bit').
This document shows internal Bureau of Prisons discussions about Epstein's vulnerability and housing arrangements prior to his death.
